B000002UAU|5.0|The Beatles stunned critics, took their millions of fans by surprise, and literally outdid themselves when, in 1967, they presented the Grammy Award winning Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, a rock album of epic proportions, after nearly a year on break (Revolver was their last album in 1966 before returning with Pepper).    38 years later - yes, that's right...it's been that long, Sgt Pepper's is still revered as the first real concept album. According to many people today, it was this album that would inspire other major rock bands' work like Pink Floyd's Dark Side Of The Moon and, later on, The Wall, The Who's Tommy, and pretty much most, if not all, of Led Zeppelin's work (no pun intended).     Sgt Pepper contains some of The Beatles's most powerful work, something that might please Paul McCartney since he wrote most of the material himself. The opening title track is literally a curtain raiser, with the band welcoming us to the show. The song fades right into With A Little Help From My Friends, a remarkable tune sung wonderfully by Ringo. The 'rock opera' of Sgt Pepper ends there (or does it?), just in time for John Lennon's mesmerizing, and quite controversial, Lucy In The Sky With Diamonds followed by a string of strong McCartney tunes: Getting Better, Fixing A Hole, and She's Leaving Home. Lennon returns with the extravagant Being For The Benefit Of Mr Kite, followed by Harrison's Within You Without You, a song that inspired the boys to take a 'spiritual' journey to India to visit the maharishi, something George would later take seriously while the others shrugged off. Paul comes back after that with the witty When I'm Sixty Four and Lovely Rita before John makes the final and lasting appearance on the album with, first, the experimental Good Morning Good Morning and, after the Sgt Pepper show closing Reprise, the mindblowing A Day In The Life, the highlight album closing song that stirred heads, and remains to be one of Lennon's greatest contributions to the Beatle catalogue.    Recommended    A+
B000AMJDHY|4.0|I got this CD because of some nudging from an online friend, and as a male college student, I was not disappointed.  Their sound is much like Fall Out Boy, as formerly stated, but their lyrics are more memorable and meaningful.  No, they're not the next Hendrix/Green Day/Offspring/Satriani/; but they are a blast to listen to.    The sound they have is full throtle the whole way - there isn't much room for breaks.  Most of the songs are broken up into rotating A, B, and C melodies, which really works well for some songs and gets rather dull for others.    Most of the songs will get annoying if you listen to them over and over again - if you're used to techno or fall out boy, you understand what I mean.  But if you listen to it that much, that means that you like them anyway, right?  Some of them also seem to just be words strung together, and its hard to find a cohesive meaning.  Others, like \\"Lying is the..\\" hit the perfect mark - they have a solid theme, strong lyrics and great melody.    If you're expecting the next Green Day, you can keep looking, but if you're like me and just love hearing new material, this is the stop.
B000AL730O|5.0|Whenever a new McCartney cd comes out, I never really expect much.  Although McCartney is arguably the greatest all-around musician ever, I always think that with all that he has done, how could he possibly do anything more.  For this reason, people have been hard on Paul.  He has set such a high standard for songwriting and arranging as a Beatle and in the aftermath, that people want him to always be the best songwriter in the world.  If Coldplay or Jet were to come out with a cd of the songs from McCartney's last studio work, \\"Driving Rain,\\" and people thought Coldplay or Jet had written the songs, people (critics included) would write things like, \\"Coldplay have just written the best cd of their career.  They've really improved in their ability to come up with great melodies and brilliant arrangements.\\"  Yet, with Paul McCartney, they expect more, and he gets slagged for coming up with material that even at his worst, is better than most musicians could ever invent. <br />On \\"Chaos and Creation,\\" Paul McCartney plugs into the \\"Beatle Genius\\" mode, and delivers what may his best batch of songs since \\"Revolver.\\"  The album opens with the infectious \\"Fine Line,\\" and that is the last \\"good\\" song--the rest are great.  If this were 25 years ago, or if 20-somethings could open their minds to the fact that this old guy can still write, sing, and play circles around what their current heroes, and if program directors had the courage to play the best music coming out rather than shallow song after shallow song, all with the same beat and trite lyrics, this album would be at the top of the charts for six months (ala \\"Band on the Run\\")and would be currently producing a slew of monster hits.   <br />My impression of recent McCartney work (and aside from the spotty \\"Driving Rain,\\") is that it has been excellent, but that while McCartney could still rock out with the best of 'em, his ballads were not quite as good as they used to be.  \\"Chaos\\" changes all that.  I don't believethat ever in his career has he written so many breath-taking ballads.  These songs are heart felt and introspective . . . and, you know that feeling you get when you're listening to a great song and an especially great part of the song comes and you get that euphoric goose-bump moment?  Well, this cd has more such moments than any I've ever heard, and I've heard lots of 'em.  And I can't get enough of this album.  This hasn't happened to me in years.  This is Beatle-quality stuff. <br />Paul also plays virtually all the instruments, but instead of a slightly-homemade feel such as on \\"McCartney,\\" this is very polished.  His piano playing is the best of his career.  Not only is the technique excellent, but its fit into the mix of each song is very Moby-esque; his guitar work (most of it on a semi-hollow Epiphone Casino) integrates brilliantly with every song.  <br />On past cds, I'm always waiting for Paul to let lose, to give us some of that characteristic growling scream that only he can do, like on \\"Birthday\\" or \\"Oh Woman, Oh Why?\\", but this cd is so damned good that it doesn't even need it.  Admittedly, I never thought I'd like a McCartney record without some hard rock, but I guess he proved me wrong.  <br />What's more amazing is that even Beatles albums had a bit of filler.  This has none.  It's all superior stuff.  Paul might be coming into one of those super creative periods like he had in the late 60s.  Would that be cool or what! <br />It might take a year's worth of retrospect to figure out where this work rates on McCartney's list.  He's made more great ones than anyone else, at least in the pop/rock genre.  It certainly rates with \\"Abbey Road,\\" \\"Revolver,\\" \\"The White Album,\\" \\"Sgt Pepper,\\" \\"Magical Mystery Tour,\\" \\"Band on the Run,\\" \\"Wings Over America,\\" \\"Unplugged,\\" \\"Ram,\\" \\"Tug of War,\\" \\"Flowers in the Dirt,\\" \\"Run Devil Run,\\" and \\"Flaming Pie\\"--right now, after a dozen or so listens, I'm apt to call it his crowning achievement, the best record he has evermade.  <br /> <br />

0764110284|4.0|An excellent workbook for learning phrasal verbs in English. However, I have found quite a few mistakes/misprints in the answer section. Some are minor: verbs and particles are separated where they should be put together one after the other; others a bit more serious: a phrasal verb that is appropriate in meaning but not covered in the given unit is offered as an answer to the quiz, or simply wrong ones are provided. Otherwise, I would have given 5 stars. I hope that there aren't as many mistakes/misprints in the text itself, and that the publisher will correct them for the next edition.

0440234743|4.0|I've resisted reading Grisham novels because of a personal bias, mainly, I'm disgusted in things dealing with lawyers.  But putting that aside this one time last October because I was looking to expand what I read, I'm pleasantly surprised by the outcome.    The lives of the multibillionaire, Troy Phelan, and of his big money-grubbing family were a delicious read.  There's a tabloid flavor whenever you get to those Phelan heir sections.  The lawyer protagonist character, Nate, was semi-sympathetic (many problems in his life like alcohol abuse, alienation from family members, financial problems, bad habits stemming from a wild life).  But I found that I didn't care for him much, although I did root for him at the end. I also found that I wanted him to face life's consequences, as almost all of us have to, who don't have the privileges that Nate had.      Reading about the Pantanal was great.  It is hard for Westerners to fathom living in a place so remote and isolated from modern conveniences (like hospitals!).  It is so true that what our society tries to make you care about (headlines in newspapers and news stories on TV) seem so unimportant when given the backdrop of a Pantanal lifestyle where life is simple, fragile, and deeply affected by the weather, where death from treatable conditions and sicknesses (snakebites, malaria, and dengue fever in the book) happen easily.  It is one of those places you'd want to visit but would think twice about living in. I am glad that Grisham found and worked this location into the story.
B000002UB3|5.0|It sounds like a weighty task, coming up with your favorite album of all time. But for me, it was an easy, no-contest kind of thing, which is testament to how much I love this record: Abbey Road by the Beatles. It's an amazingly cohesive piece of music, innovative and timeless. All that, plus the knowledge that this was the band's last work together. A brilliant, unforgettable farewell.  <br /> <br />As John Lennon himself griped, talking about music is a bit like talking about sex; it's better to experience it than describe it. That being said, I will do my best to articulate why this album rests comfortably at the top of my list. Before getting in to those specifics, I will also say I think it's especially important in the case of Abbey Road to look beyond the actual songs to what was going on behind the scenes at the time of its making.  <br /> <br />Only five years after their appearance on the Ed Sullivan show, the Beatles had weathered insanely crazed tours, changing fashions and social mores (which they helped define), the growing drug culture, and the increasing demands of their personal lives. While three of the four members had met as teenagers, they were -- all still in their 20s -- worldly beyond their years.  <br /> <br />Most recently, the Beatles survived the debacle of Let It Be, but barely. (While Let It Be was released after Abbey Road -- and after the announcement of the breakup in April 1970 -- it was recorded first, during a miserable winter of the band's discontent in early 1969). So discouraged were the Fabs by the final product, that Paul -- ever the cheerleader -- convinced the others that they could, indeed, do better. George Martin, turned off by the captured-on-film squabbling during the Let It Be sessions, agreed to return to the studio only if he could have real authority and \\"the boys\\" were better behaved.  <br /> <br />While tensions remained during the recording, of Abbey Road in the summer of 1969, the Beatles made a concerted effort to make a great album. And they succeeded. George Martin himself has called it his favorite Beatles album.  <br /> <br />In the context of my own life, I was just starting sixth grade when Abbey Road was released in September 1969; by the time the school year was out, the band was no more. I remember listening to Abbey Road over and over till every song was embedded in my 12-year-old brain. The fact this album still enthralls me so is testament to its timelessness.  <br /> <br />I felt very grown-up buying Abbey Road with my babysitting money -- it was the first real \\"rock\\" album I ever owned. This was a less esoteric and more radio-friendly record than 1968's The Beatles, a.k.a. \\"The White Album\\". In addition to the obsessive playing of Abbey Road, I recall getting fully caught up in the \\"Paul Is Dead\\" brouhaha that followed its release. (Remember the \\"meaning\\" of the album cover? John, in white, was \\"God\\"; Ringo, in black, the \\"undertaker\\"; dungarees-dressed George was the \\"gravedigger\\". And Paul ... well, Paul was striding across that album cover barefoot, which meant -- in some ancient culture that was always very vague -- that he was the \\"dead man\\".) Ah, the memories. Now onto to the music.  <br /> <br />It's the summer of Woodstock, of the Manson murders, of Chappaquidick, and despite the growing tension within the band, Abbey Road is recorded without any major hassles, proving that the Beatles retained their musical magic right 'til the end. Their chemistry was so perfect, so right-on that even their splintering existence could not tarnish it. They quit at the top of their game; perhaps that's why fans never could quite accept that break-up, constantly asking them when, if they would ever reunite.  <br /> <br />From the potent opener, \\"Come Together\\" -- with its weirdly ominous \\"Shoot Me\\" sung by Lennon -- to the final strains of \\"The End\\", Abbey Road managed to give each member of the band a chance to shine on their own, while contributing to the bigger picture as a seemingly cohesive foursome.  <br /> <br />Abbey Road is especially noteworthy in my book because it contains two of George Harrison's best songs as a Beatle: \\"Something\\" and \\"Here Comes the Sun\\". While Harrison's work was always overshadowed by the Lennon/McCartney hitmaking machine, I've never failed to be impressed by what good songs he did write, with hardly any support or attention given by the aforementioned leaders.  <br /> <br />On \\"Something\\", George's passionate guitar solo fleshes out the lyrics' sense of yearning, and George Martin's subtle, sophisticated orchestral score frames the song itself. \\"Here Comes the Sun\\", meanwhile, has an amazingly catchy hook -- so pure that it gets lodged in the brain in a matter of seconds through the expert finger-picking that opens the song.  <br /> <br />Other highlights on Abbey Road include Paul's bluesy, wailing, \\"Oh! Darling\\", (which Lennon reportedly wanted to sing, he liked it so much) and John's equally impassioned but more avant-garde \\"I Want You (She's So Heavy)\\". Even Ringo's \\"Octopus's Garden\\" has a certain whimsical charm that works.  <br /> <br />The highlight of Abbey Road, for me, has to be the 16-minute medley that, back in the days when there were albums with two sides, closed out side two. Paul has to be given credit for this; structurally, the medley was his baby and his songs -- \\"You Never Give Me Your Money\\", \\"She Came in through the Bathroom Window\\", \\"Golden Slumbers\\", and \\"Carry That Weight\\" -- are the standouts. Still, the medley wouldn't work without Lennon's contributions -- his \\"Polythene Pam\\" and \\"Sun King\\" add to the effortless flow of the musical stream-of-consciousness.  <br /> <br />While the band wasn't aware of its impending breakup -- at least, not on the surface -- the closing track, \\"The End\\" truly did signify just that, and each Beatle got a chance to shine individually before they closed up shop and went away to become the Plastic Ono Band and Wings.  <br /> <br />Firstwe get Ringo's one-and-only drum solo, and it's a catchy, inspired, rollicking gem. Then comes the \\"Love You\\" choruses that lead into the amazing guitar round robin. Paul starts it off (showing that he was always a kick-ass guitarist despite being relegated to bass), then comes George's distinctive riffs, followed by John's howling, wailing guitar. A lone piano emerges from the din, and all three sing the line, \\"And in the end / The love you take / Is equal to the love you make\\", closing out the record with a sense of, well, completion.  <br /> <br />(Ends up, though, that \\"The End\\" wasn't quite the end; the then-hidden ditty, \\"Her Majesty\\", followed after a brief pause, having the record end on an \\"up\\", rather than solemn, note).  <br /> <br />While the creepy-cheerful \\"Maxwell's Silver Hammer\\" always seemed a bit out of place to me on Abbey Road, I can't flog Paul too much over that since it was basically his pushing and prodding and nudging and nagging that got the band back into the studio for this final masterpiece the first place.  <br /> <br />While it bugs the heck out of me that McCartney wants have his name to come first on Beatles's songs now -- how big is this guy's ego, anyway? -- I have to begrudgingly forgive all that because of the amazing, timeless Abbey Road. For this record alone, he deserved to be knighted.  <br /> <br />

067101756X|1.0|I'm always open-minded, including regarding the events on that fateful night in Roswell, New Mexico. And for the first 30, 40 pages or so, Corso really had me going. (and the numerous fake 5-star reviews for this book might trick you into buying it).    Then it started to come together: why would the U.S. government entrust a no-name, low-level military man to single-handedly reverse engineer technology found on a crashed UFO? Corso claims to be personally responsible for everything from fiber optics to stealth technology.    The clues start coming together. For example, Corso claimed to have evidence the USA was planning a moonbase for battling aliens. His proof? A regular ol' picture of the moon, probably shot from his backyard with a Polaroid, which he labeled a \\"reconaissance picture\\" for the moonbase.    As the book goes on, the tales get taller and taller; I quit when Corso claimed the Soviets and aliens from outer space had a secret military alliance against the US.    Whatever and wherever the event, Corso just happened to be there, whether in Roswell that night, the following days when he accidentally caught a glimpse of the dead \\"ETs,\\" and meetings with the President himself. I didn't finish the book, but perhaps he went on to claim observing aliens building the Pyramids of Egypt. Kind of like Forest Gump. And Corso's about as bright as Gump, too.    Conveniently, the very elderly and certainly demented Corso died not long after the book was published. He left his wife and family a very nice life insurance policy in the form of a royalty payments from this very silly fish tale.    If you really want to learn about what happened at Roswell, visit the UFO museum there, which is filled with interesting (and factual) information that allows the individual to intelligently decide what really happened that evening long ago.
B000BW7QWW|3.0|I should perhaps explain where I'm coming from to provide perspective and context for my review: I've been an avid sf reader for more than half a century, an active member of sf fandom almost as long and I'm a published writer of sf and fantasy. I'm also an unabashed Joss Whedon fan. (I didn't much care for the \\"Buffy\\" movie, so owe this to my daughter's urging to watch the tv series; I now have all seasons of Buffy and Angel on DVD, as well as Firefly and Serenity, and even Tim Minear's Wonder Falls.)  <br /> <br />But I'm something of a snob when it comes to movies. I make distinctions between sf and \\"sci fi\\"; the former are rare, the latter being generally distinguished by containing either \\"dumbed-down\\" science or, worse, stupid scientific mistakes (and are sometimes even anti-science). I never ran into the problem with Buffy or Angel because they're fantasy, where you can pretty much make it up as you go (although internal consistency is a definite plus).  <br /> <br />But when you lose all scientific credibility in sci fi, you generally lose the respect of any sf readers. Both Firefly and Serenity manage to come down with major scientific blunders, and while as an sf reader this does sadden me, you'll note I've still purchased the DVDs of both. Like fingernails on a blackboard, they're annoying; but it's possible to shudder and move on if there's any acceptable reason to do so.  <br /> <br />I've encountered my share of people who claim to be sf fans who are really just fans of sci fi SFX, but I'm afraid not even the finest eye candy has ever made me respect that segment of the genre; Firefly and Serenity are only rescued to the extent they are not by technical wizardry but by Joss Whedon's forte, compelling character-driven story telling. It's still sci fi, so the series and the movie are, for me at least, a guilty pleasure. And, sure, I wish Joss had a decent science advisor, because it would not have been hard to make his sci fi series and movie into real science fiction but, oh, well, I guess you really can't have everything. <br /> <br />The ignorance ranges from the far-reaching and general to the specific. Characters use words like 'verse (as in \\"universe\\") and galaxy apparently without any knowledge of what they really mean. Firefly/Serenity's basic premise is flawed: A star-system with a G-type sun relatively close to ours with \\"hundreds\\" of roughly Earth-sized planets and moons close enough to that sun for us to colonize and terraform them, yet far enough from each other that some would be \\"central\\" and others would be at a significantly greater distance away from that supposed \\"core,\\" is a contradiction too great to be believed even with both eyes closed real tight and your hands firmly covering them. One of the best-told stories of the series, the episode entitled \\"Out of Gas,\\" unfortunately highlights the fact that Whedon (and those working with him) is abysmally ignorant of basic science, as it violates Newton's First Law of Motion.   <br /> <br />But the story-telling! Oh, yeah! Fully realized flesh-and-blood three-dimensional characters doing and saying things that make us *care about* what happens to them.  You just won't find this in sci fi movies -- or most science fiction movies, either, I must admit.  It makes the series and the movie into sci fi that even an sf reader could love. <br /> <br />Regretfully, as a fan of the series, I must add that the movie was a bit of a disappointment. It was twice as long but had about half the emotional depth of a single average series episode -- and what emotional impact the movie had was almost entirely dependent on having seen the series. A couple of the Good Guys get it in the neck, but neither of them have been developed sufficiently in the movie to make their deaths meaningful to the movie audience; we haven't even seen enough of Zoe for most who may first come across her in the movie to realize how atypically nearly suicidal she becomes as the film is reaching its climax. Almost everything in the movie that has emotional resonance is dependent on knowing more about the characters than the movie chooses to tell the viewer. <br /> <br />The motion picture, finally, is not quite set in the same universe as the tv series. The opening scene shows Simon's rescue of his sister Summer, in which he takes a very active part and learns a great deal about what was done to her; in the series, Simon arranged (through the payment of a great deal of money) for her rescue but did not take part in it and had to learn what the Alliance had done to her over a period of time. The captain also appears to regard them as passengers who need to earn their keep, having apparently forgotten that in the series he had already made Simon part of the crew for his surgical expertise. <br /> <br />Then too, the only scene which gives the viewer any understanding of what a Companion is has been deleted from the final cut; given that Mal disguises himself as a monk to rescue Inara and that she lights incense (that isn't actually incense) and begins to pray for him when she first sees him while he is trying to do so would probably make movie-goers who'd not seen the series think she must be some kind of a nun. (Not a typo.) <br /> <br />The movie has not been a box office success, as it has yet to earn back its costs in ticket sales. It would appear that few people who were not fans of the series actually went to the theater to see it. If DVD sales are fairly high, it might yet wind up in the black, but alas those who canceled the series (and who may have opposed making the movie) appear to be vindicated, since these figures will almost certainly be cited to prove that the tv and movie-going audiences prefer cute aliens, wacky robot sidekicks and mindless SFX to character-driven stories in their sci fi (or, for that matter, even in the rare science fiction) movies and tv fare. The liklihood that there will be future films in the Serenity universe, giventhese facts, seems extremely low.                <br /> <br />It nonetheless earns, flaws and all, three stars from me. But a little more attention to detail, more character development for those who came new to it at the movies and putting in the effort to make it science fiction might have renderd this a five-star movie.  Alas. <br /> <br />--rich brown a.k.a. Dr Gafia
1400077915|5.0|It doesn't matter if you have heard of Alice Munro or not.  This collection of short stories by one of the best short writers in the world bespeaks of sensitivity and a high mastery of the craft of writing.<br /><br />The stories are about women and love in all of its forms.  Deceit, trust, love, desire and regret.  The protagonists in each story are well thought out individuals, not a false note in any of them.  Alice Munro succeeds in telling a story without slipping into a basket of clich's, rather telling stories as they really do happen in real life without a twinge of regret for having done so.  Her characters are introspective while very much being a part of the world they inhabit.  They are strong, weak, they have faults, in essence, they are believable which is the highest compliment a writer can receive.<br /><br />Anyone wishing to learn the craft of writing short stories would do well to start here.
B000021XR5|4.0|Stone Temple Pilots touched heavily upon their Beatles influence on 1996's strong but shaky TINY MUSIC. After such, singer Scott Weiland began to battle his troubling drug addictions, and he made the news quite frequently, even landing himself some jail time in the process. But when he finally recovered, the quartet got back together and made NO. 4, arguably a great record that, while not at all a failure, has very minor quibbles that are easily forgiven thanks to the dynamics that the band have recaptured quite nicely here. The DeLeo brothers still churn out monster riffs and a thumping bass to compliment drummer Eric Kretz's crazy fills, all providing solid ground for Scott Weiland's enigmatic performance...he really is a true vocalist, whether on-stage or on-studio.  <br /> <br />NO. 4 is big on variety, ranging from full-throttle rockers (leadoff single \\"Down\\") to fairly melancholy, even lush fare (tearjerking closer \\"Atlanta). But what's great is the music, for the most part, is particularly strong again, and on cuts like the break-neck \\"Heaven & Hot Rods\\", you can't help but shake, bang your head, or go crazy. It's full throttle of guitars and thwomping rhythms make it an easily memorable track. STP still harbor some Beatles influence on cuts like the likable and melodic \\"Sour Girl\\" and the 60s feel of \\"I Got You\\". But the all jam feel of the rockin' \\"MC5\\" and the blistering \\"Sex And Violence\\" bring you right back into the ring. Throughout this 11-song set, STP seem to feel good again about making music, and it shows in their performance and energy on this collection. <br /> <br />So while no true classic, NO. 4 is definitely a welcome surprise from STP who, while highly successful, have been plagued by their fair share of troubles. But while that's clear now, what is evident is that this disc rocks and rolls along, and it's good to hear this quartet finding their ground again.
0316776963|4.0|David Sedaris is at his best when writing about his family, as he does in many of the essays in ME TALK PRETTY ONE DAY. When he is not funny is when he is being self-depricating. (sp?)<br /><br />I really enjoyed this collection of essays - they are laugh outloud funny, and some, such as the story of his parents' Great Dane, or  \\"My Childhood in Africa\\", where Sedaris attempts to replace his boring childhood memories with his boyfriend's: field-trips to slaughterhouses, having a pet monkey, etc.<br /><br />They get particularly annoying, however, when Sedaris starts picking on himself. Sedaris is an incredibly capable writer, one who can tell a mundane story in a way that will have even the most stoned-faced person spitting milk out of their nose, and yet he continues to ruminate on his own stupidity, which makes average writers like myself hate him. He also seems to possess aa sort of vain attachment to his faults, and this too is annoying.<br /><br />This collection is highly recommended, but don't expect to enjoy every essay.

B000002KET|5.0|Sabbath Bloody Sabbath(1973). Black Sabbath's Fifth Album.<br /><br />In 1973, Black Sabbath were still a heavy-hitter, but instead of playing arena concerts they were playing modest-sized concerts. After Master of Reality, Sabbath couldn't seem to get a big hit, but their albums still sold well because of Black Sabbath's huge fanbase. No. 4, while being a great album, failed to produce a solid hit, so Black Sabbath went on tour and went to the studio to record Sabbath Bloody Sabbath. Sabbath Bloody Sabbath would go on to be considered Black Sabbath's finest moment to many, boasting such fan favorites as \\"Sabbra Caddabra\\", \\"Sabbath Bloody Sabbath\\", and \\"Killing Yourself To Live\\". It was clear that Sabbath were still in their prime, and fans went out and bought the album even without the help of a hit single.<br /><br />With Sabbath Bloody Sabbath, Black Sabbath stuck to their tried and true formula of crunching guitar, evil lyrics, and piercing singing, but they added some new elements to their sound, such as keyboards and synthesizers. Black Sabbath would later go on to make this a major part of their sound, and this is the first album where they experimented with it. Black Sabbath opens with \\"Sabbath Bloody Sabbath\\", the classic Black Sabbath masterpiece. Heavy and thundering, Black Sabbath quickly shows that this is one of their all-time best. \\"A National Acrobat\\", while not being very well known, is a pump-your-fist and headbang metal classic. Slow and progressive, the track is a perfect mix of powerful riffs and haunting singing. While Sabbath is not very well known for being \\"progressive\\", where bands continually shift their sound within a song, many times on Sabbath Bloody Sabbath they seem very progressive. \\"Fluff\\", as the title might suggest is some very basic filler, but it's not bad at all. A nice beautiful little acoustic guitar piece from Tony Iommi may not fit in well with the album, but it's a good offering. \\"Sabbra Cadabra\\" is another Black Sabbath favorite, a loud and dirty hard rocker that never fails to get your head banging. Insanely powerful riffs and vocals make this song one of Black Sabbath's most agressive offerings. Metallica made their own cover of this classic, but Black Sabbath couldn't be outdone, their version is much better! \\"Killing Yourself To Live\\" is a classic groovy metal tune, starting off slow and picking up into an evil and powerful rocker. Very catchy, Iommi displays his insane guitar talents on this track. \\"Who Are You?\\" is a rather bland synthesizer driven tune, and it suffers from repetisism. There is some nice keyboard work here, but this track still stands as the only mediocre song to be found. \\"Spiral Architect\\" does *not* sound like Black Sabbath, but more like Rush or Yes. A truly beautiful and haunting track, it's a very progressive and thunderous tune that serves as one of Sabbath's finest moments. The album closes with \\"Looking For Today\\", a punkish hard rocker full of attitude. Black Sabbath uses some very soothing orchestration to great effect here. Perfect way to close an album.<br /><br />Sabbath Bloody Sabbath is a classic heavy metal album, and to me clearly Black Sabbath's finest effort. Every song here, with the exception of \\"Fluff\\" and \\"Who Are You?\\" are classics. Black Sabbath's use of keyboards, synths, and orchestration shows them branching out musically, and their song structures became much more progressive and focused on Sabbath Bloody Sabbath. To put it simply, this album rocks. I encourage any fan of hard rock, heavy metal, or Black Sabbath to pick this up or your collection isn't complete!<br /><br />Also Recommended<br /><br />Black Sabbath - Paranoid<br /><br />Deep Purple - Machine Head<br /><br />Ted Nugent - Cat Scratch Fever<br /><br />Thanks For Readingath favorite, a loud and dirty hard rocker that never fails to get your head banging. Insanely powerful riffs and vocals make this song one of Black Sabbath's most agressive offerings. Metallica made their own cover of this classic, but Black Sabbath couldn't be outdone, their version is much better! \\"Killing Yourself To Live\\" is a classic groovy metal tune, starting off slow and picking up into an evil and powerful rocker. Very catchy, Iommi displays his insane guitar talents on this track. \\"Who Are You?\\" is a rather bland synthesizer driven tune, and it suffers from repetisism. There is some nice keyboard work here, but this track still stands as the only mediocre song to be found. \\"Spiral Architect\\" does *not* sound like Black Sabbath, but more like Rush or Yes. A truly beautiful and haunting track, it's a very progressive and thunderous tune that serves as one of Sabbath's finest moments. The album closes with \\"Looking For Today\\", a punkish hard rocker full of attitude. Black Sabbath uses some very soothing orchestration to great effect here. Perfect way to close an album. <br /> <br />Sabbath Bloody Sabbath is a classic heavy metal album, and to me clearly Black Sabbath's finest effort. Every song here, with the exception of \\"Fluff\\" and \\"Who Are You?\\" are classics. Black Sabbath's use of keyboards, synths, and orchestration shows them branching out musically, and their song structures became much more progressive and focused on Sabbath Bloody Sabbath. Every single song, which beautifully blends in from one to the next, qualifies for a top 10 hit!  If it's not already, trust me, it will be.      They're all GREAT, but my favorite stand-outs are cuts #3, the fantastic bass driven \\"Sorry\\" ; #5, an extremely powerful \\"I Love New York\\" ; #7, the very sensitive/heart tugging  \\"Forbidden Love\\" ; #8, the dreamy and strong \\"Jump\\"; and #12, the snap your fingers, clap your hands, and /or tap your feet \\"Like It Or Not\\" . Now, I saved THE best one for last, ..... #4 , the Donna Summer-I Feel Love/Madonna-Ray Of Light influenced \\"Future Lovers\\". Absolutely  riviting!  Wow!! ....\\"There is no love like the future love\\".........   P.S. You have my blessings to put this track on repeat mode.     P.S.S. Note to Madonna:I hope to meet you someday in person so I can thank you for the music and congratulate you on a brilliant masterpiece ! ...... John Pollack , Glendale Heights, IL

B000B8QG0O|5.0|What could be better than the 2-disc \\"Toy Story\\"? Well, you can try the equally-superb \\"Toy Story 2\\" in the same 2-disc format. Yes, your Pixar collection is now complete thanks to this, the movie that took Woody and Buzz to places no toy had yet gone before. <br />        As with the first installment, the movie looks and sounds terrific thanks to a cleaned-up print and, again, the good work of sound master Gary Rydstrom. You can see the bright toy colors and clickety-clack sounds like new. Also, the computer process had advanced enough by now that both the human characters and the action settings looked more realistic- especially the airport in the final segments. <br />        \\"Toy Story 2\\" also boasts a very clever story line that's both a loving throwback to vintage kiddie shows and good- <br />natured satire on both mega-toy stores and collectible mania. Both are exemplified in a wacky new character, Al the Toy Guy (voice of Wayne Knight), the rotund and manic toy retailer who's also crazy about his \\"Woody's Roundup\\" memorabilia.  <br />        \\"Woody's Roundup\\"? Here's what I really love about this movie. The greatest old-time kiddie show never aired, this is \\"Howdy Doody\\" meets \\"Hopalong Cassidy\\" and Woody's unknown-to-Andy roots. Through a roomful of '50s-style toys, a kinescope- <br />style flashback, three new come-to-life characters and a nifty cowboy-style theme song, Pixar's John Lasseter and his team create a delightful homage to vintage children's TV. The collectible part? Al's made a lucrative deal to deliver Woody and the gang, personally, to a Japanese toy museum. <br />          Between the mysterious disappearance of Woody and the exciting rescue from a Tokyo-bound jet, we revisit all the much- <br />loved characters from the first \\"Toy Story\\". Particularly funny are Hamm (John Ratzenberger), the gruff piggy bank, and both Mr. and Mrs. Potato Head. Estelle Harris makes the latter into a classic Brooklyn Jewish/Edith Bunker mother, a perfect match for Don Rickles (\\"I'm a married spud!\\"). Of course, of all the things Tom Hanks and Tim Allen have done, it's their wonderful Woody-and-Buzz banter that might last longer than anything. Don't miss a fusty (is he anything else?) Kelsey Grammer as Stinky Pete the Prospector, either. <br />         The format of this edition is identical to the one for the first \\"Toy Story\\", with a great batch of bonus items on Disc 2. Character and set-design galleries give you a detailed look at how elaborate film construction unfolds. Lasseter's the proverbial kid in the candy store as he displays all those cheesy \\"Woody's Roundup\\" toys. Rydstrom's back with a game that lets you see how sound mixing works. There's even a welcome appearance by Riders in the Sky, a veteran Western-billy band that does a lively \\"Roundup\\" medley. Both that song and \\"When She Loved Me\\", Jessie the cowgirl's soft, nostalgic ballad (sung by Sarah McLachlan), were penned- as was all Pixar-related music until 2002- by the wonderful Randy Newman. <br />        \\"Toy Story 2\\"- and \\"Toy Story\\", too!- are movies whose appeal is across the board, easy enough for four-year-olds, witty enough for college kids, and well-drawn (both design and character) enough for literate adults. They're, as I like to say, \\"awesomely simple\\". The beauty of Pixar is that, though the technology, bells and whistles get ever more sophisticated, they never lose track of making movies that are about strong characters and realistic situations- whether they're working with piggy banks or one-eyed green monsters. What more could a movie maker or viewer ask for?  <br />       We're told that a \\"Toy Story 3\\" is on the storyboards. Can Pixar- and, hopefully, its once and future business partners at Disney- keep this franchise fresh and wondrous? I certainly think so. Meanwhile, there's much to enjoy here.
B000E97Y6K|5.0|The early reviews were some of the best ever for a \\"popcorn\\" film, and King Kong lives up to that acclaim. For pure action, excitement and cinema awe, there is no equal. Audiences are glued to their seats during the chase and fight scenes, and many people are moved to tears with the tender moments between Kong and Ann (Naomi Watts). But people are staying away, and those who attend do not describe it as a rewarding experience. Why? Because the film is too massive, too exciting. In a word, it is \\"overwhelming\\".<br /><br />The story is well known: a group of filmmakers (lead by Jack Black as the crew's director) travel to the remote Skull Island, a hidden world that does not appear on maps and can only be found by wayward ships lost in the fog. The island is one forgotten by time. Dinosaurs inhabit the island, but the king beast is Kong, a massive ape-like figure who uproots trees and de-jaws T-Rexs during his daily activities.<br /><br />Of course, the ship's beautiful blonde passenger becomes the object of Kong's desire and they develop a relationship that drives the film's action. Unlike previous incarnations of this story, Peter Jackson's version of King Kong allows the Ape and the girl to actually bond. In the PC world, he doesn't like her \\"only\\" because she is beautiful and blonde; he likes her because they share some happy moments together, making the final all the more tragic.<br /><br />The photography is beautiful, from the haunting jungles of Skull Island to the flapper-era street scenes of New York. Of course, the film's iconic moment takes place stop the Empire State Building, a scene brought to life under a stunning Monet-like sky. The most awesome visual feature is Kong himself. So real and so lifelike that viewers quickly forget they are watching a fantasy story.<br /><br />There is nothing bad to say about the film. The performances fit the story perfectly, with Jack Black irresistible as the gung-ho showman. The effects, sets, costumes, etc all show how great movies can look when their monumental budgets are used responsibly. But again, people only like this film; they don't love it. Why?<br /><br />It is just too much. The film could really use a thriftier editing. By removing an hour, the experience of viewing the film would leave people excited about the story without being exhausted from the viewing. And removing an hour would not damage the story. The most obvious subplots to cut involve the other passengers on the ship, especially their journey to rescue Ann on Skull Island. While they search for her, the film becomes unwisely similar to Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings films. The group of ragtag would-be rescuers battles all kinds of adversities (giant bugs, dinosaurs, dangerous cliffs, etc) to get to Ann and her captor. This action has little to do with the main story (Ann and Kong's relationship) and could be removed without damaging the story.<br /><br />It is not a perfect film, and clearly improvements can be made. But there is still a lot to like, especially for young viewers (or the kid in all of us). In its current form, King Kong is to teenage boys what Titanic was to teenage girls; the kind of film that will find its way into the dreams of its viewers for many years.tc all show how great movies can look when their monumental budgets are used responsibly. But again, people only like this film; they don't love it. Why?  <br /> <br />It is just too much. The film could really use a thriftier editing. By removing an hour, the experience of viewing the film would leave people excited about the story without being exhausted from the viewing. And removing an hour would not damage the story. The most obvious subplots to cut involve the other passengers on the ship, especially their journey to rescue Ann on Skull Island. While they search for her, the film becomes unwisely similar to Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings films. The group of ragtag would-be rescuers battles all kinds of adversities (giant bugs, dinosaurs, dangerous cliffs, etc) to get to Ann and her captor. This action has little to do with the main story (Ann and Kong's relationship) and could be removed without damaging the story.  <br /> <br />It is not a perfect film, and clearly improvements can be made. But there is still a lot to like, especially for young viewers (or the kid in all of us). In its current form, King Kong is to teenage boys what Titanic was to teenage girls; the kind of film that will find its way into the dreams of its viewers for many years. <br />
B000BMSTMS|3.0|As you look through the reviews on this Korn album, I think you will see two different styles of reviews:      Reviews from people who love anything and everything Korn puts out.  Seriously, it could be 75 minutes of Jonathan Davis farting and they will give it 5 stars,     or Reviews from people who hate Korn, who grew tired of them in 1999 (or hate them because everyone else says they do), and will say that \\"See You on the Other Side\\" sounds \\"like every other album they've ever done\\".  They won't really say WHY it is a bad CD, but they will probably end their review by recommending a bunch of obscure death metal bands instead.    Well, I'm going to try and be a third type of reviewer:  A die-hard Korn fan who is realistic.  I encourage you to read my reviews of \\"Untouchables\\" and \\"Take a Look in the Mirror\\" to understand the Korn story and how long I have listened to them.  In short, I have all the albums, have listened to them since 1995, and have seen them 5 times in concert.    Well, 2005 was an interesting year for the 5 (now 4) members of Korn.  Longtime guitarist Brian \\"Head\\" Welch announced he had found Jesus and left the band, citing Jonathan's vulgar lyrics and his own personal drug problem.  It became sort of a running joke, with Tool/A Perfect Circle vocalist Maynard James Keenan parodying the whole thing as an April Fool's Day joke.  Head still has not been replaced, but former Otep guitarist Rob Patterson has filled in as a touring guitarist---off stage.  Yeah, the band won't let him play out there with them.  I thought it was strange too.  Hey, Green Day has a touring guitarist.  What's his name?  Heck, I don't know, but at least he can stand out there with them.    Anyway, back to the album.  Like every Korn CD of the past 6 years, the band announced that \\"See You on the Other Side\\" was \\"the best thing we've ever done\\".  Well, I thought \\"Untouchables\\" was.  Or maybe it was \\"Take a Look in the Mirror\\", since the band said the same thing about both ofthose CD's.  Well, the one thing they were forthcoming about was that they were experimenting with new sounds, and that they had hired pop producers The Matrix (no, not the movie, but the 3 person team who produced and wrote Avril Lavigne's \\"Let Go\\" album) and Dallas Clark to produce, engineer, and *GASP!* help write songs on the album.    Korn fans around the country were horrified that a mainstream pop producing act might have taken over writing duties for the band.  The rumor was that Head was the one with all the talent, and that the band couldn't work well without him (much like Limp Bizkit without Wes Borland).  Well, Korn DID write most of the music.  The Matrix and Clark simply contributed to arrangement ideas and song structure.  It works very well on some songs, but not on others.    The opening track (and single), \\"Twisted Transistor\\", is the one song you've probably heard.  It's pop sounding, but not in a \\"Commercial Radio\\" way.  More like a \\"The Hand that Feeds\\" (by Nine Inch Nails, obviously) way.  It's really not a good song, and it seems like a lame attempt by Korn to write a catchy, radio friendly hit.  After \\"Ya'll Want a Single\\" and it's subsequent video, I thought they weren't about that.  There is a overuse of samples and overdubbing on this song.  What is Jonathan saying in the pre-chorus?  \\"Use it to?\\"  \\"Music Do?\\"  It sounds like when the radio version of the song bleeps out a swear word.  Not a good start.    However, \\"Politics\\" is amazing.  Jonathan's lyrics are a little hokey, but the overall song structure and chorus are especially well done.  \\"Hypocrites\\" takes an obvious stab at Head (\\"Your messiah was never mine\\")--even though Jonathan says it is directed at RELIGION, not Head.  Uh huh.  Another good song, one of the few that sound like the old Korn.    \\"Souvenir\\" was originally titled \\"Souvenir of Sadness\\", which was the original title of the album.  Why it was changed, I have no idea.  It is slower than most Korn songs, but just asheavy.  Not in a \\"bang your head\\" way, but it has a lot of weight in it's sound.  \\"10 or a 2-Way\\" is a pretty generic song.  Some have said Jonathan's heavy breathing at the end is supposed to be Darth Vader.  I think it's supposed to simulate sex, even though it does sound like the Sith Lord.    \\"Throw Me Away\\" is very Nine Inch Nails like, and sounds like \\"Hollow Life\\" from \\"Untouchables\\".  It's a song very heavy on samples, and falls into the \\"experimental\\" category.  \\"Love Song\\" isn't the famous song by The Cure, in case you were wondering.  Other than the chorus, it isn't anything special.    Man, this is getting tedious.  Let me cut to the chase.  \\"Open Up\\", \\"Getting Off\\" and \\"For No One\\" are all throwaways.  Not that they are bad songs, and they all have their catchy parts, but your life won't change when you listen to them.  \\"Seen it All\\" and \\"Tearjerker\\" are failed \\"experiments\\".  It was like they were trying to write some legendary quirky breakthrough song, like Tool's \\"Third Eye\\".  Sorry guys, but it didn't work.    \\"Coming Undone\\"  will be the 2nd single, and is more catchy (and a better song) than \\"Twisted Transistor\\".  \\"Liar\\" is the most \\"Original flavor\\" Korn song on the CD, and the one getting the most love from the die-hards.  I thought it was good, but there are other heavy songs that are better, like \\"Politics\\" and \\"Hypocrites\\".    I bought the Special Edition of this album, which is the one to get if you decide to buy it.  The extra tracks are, shall I dare say--better than the actual album.  \\"It's Me Again\\" has a terrific pre-chorus (\\"You see beauty, I see pain/You see sky and I see acid rain\\"), but Jonathan screams \\"It's Me Again\\" way, way too many times.  \\"Eaten Up Inside\\" is the best track on EITHER CD, with an outstanding chorus (\\"I never got what I wanted/I never got what I needed\\") and the first appearance of David using a DOUBLE KICK DRUM.    \\"Last Legal Drug\\" is slow, like \\"Souvenir\\", and better.  It has a catchy hook like \\"Coming Undone\\".  And yes, the chorus of this song is included as a bridge in \\"10 or a 2-Way\\".  The Bonus disc rounds out with 2 \\"Twisted Transistor\\" remixes (the \\"Dummies Club\\" one has become quite the hit around the club circuit) and live videos of \\"Twisted Transistor\\" and Hypocrites\\" from Moscow (only via a CD-ROM--it's not a DVD like the \\"Greatest Hits\\" album).    I've never been one to review each SONG on a CD, but I thought it was necessary this time around, because it's hard to describe this to Korn fans.  Most of the album doesn't sound anything like previous Korn releases.  Well, it's obvious Korn is trying to evolve and get away from the \\"Nu-Metal\\" movement, which has become more of a dirty word in music than \\"Grunge\\".  Every band, from Limp Bizkit to Papa Roach sounds nothing like they did on their first album, Korn included.  The problem is that Korn pioneered the sound, so everyone around them forced them to change.  I commend the guys for changing their sound up a bit and trying to evolve, but it just doesn't work.    Based on public reaction, the problem with \\"Untouchables\\" seemed to be that it was too polished, too overproduced, too straightforward, and too perfect.  At the time, I thought it was the greatest CD ever made, but now I barely listen to it, because I can't discover anything new when it's already perfected and fine tuned like it is.      The problem with \\"Take a Look in the Mirror\\" was that it was too much like the old Korn.  I personally loved it (see my review!), and found it interesting that everyone complained that it sounded too much like the self-titled album when that's the only album anyone admits to loving.    Of course, hardcore Korn fans will buy this album (like I did) and a good portion of them will call it the greatest CD ever made.  Not me.  To me, this album is a lot like \\"Issues\\"--a average album with a few great songs, and a lot of filler.  It's an average album that is hurt and brought down by the obvious desire of the 4 remaining members to evolve and become commercially viable again.  1998 and the success of \\"Follow the Leader\\" should have never happened to this band, because they seem to be obsessed with reaching that level again.  They won't admit that, of course, but it's obvious when the last 4 CD's are all different.  Korn seems like they were desperate to evolve on this album, and really, it seems like they tried too hard.  I was hoping for another \\"Take a Look In the Mirror\\".  But that album didn't sell, so I guess we won't see that side of Korn again.    I really, really, really wanted to like this album.  But because of the desire to evolve, I just couldn't get into it, even after multiple listens.  I recommend it, but not unless you either are a die-hard Korn fan, listen to their other albums first, or are open minded and understanding.  Much like Metallica's \\"St. Anger\\", I love the band, but the experiment of a CD just doesn't work.    Yes, money talks, apparantly, and we got a bloated album with intricate artwork.  And when this album doesn't sell 8 million copies like \\"Follow the Leader\\" did, expect the process to start all over again, with new producers, a new sound, and a new CD that will be \\"the best thing we've ever done\\".    EDIT:  I've never edited one of my reviews before.  However, I checked back this morning to see if my review had posted, and it had.  I then read a few pages of reviews for this CD, and discovered that my prediction about what the reviews would be like was pretty accurate.  One guy even said I was targeting HIM!  I honestly read NO reviews of this CD before I wrote mine.  Since when did Amazon turn into a message board to flame each other about the content of their reviews, OR to bash the band/director/author/politician themselves?  I guess writing under \\"A Kid's Review\\" is the hip thing to do, since no one can tell who you are.  Amazon really needs to regulate who posts on their site--and have a spell and grammar check too.  It's gotten absurd.  That isall.
B000A78Z82|4.0|Some of you might already know this, but I didn't read any mention of it in the other reviews. There is a separate or \\"hidden\\" track that is about 8 minutes long called \\"White Reggae Troll/Africa\\". So, actually, this album has 23 tracks. I think this track's title further identifies the subtle Reggae influences, infused with folk, rock, alternative, bluegrass and other genres that amalgamate into the entirety of Cripple Crow. <br /> <br />Banhart is an excellent neo-folk talent whom I first heard on Antony and the Johnson's \\"I Am a Bird Now\\" album. The tracks are musically and lyrically diverse, performed in both Spanish and English, united by a calm, earthy undertone that is pleasant like Iron and Wine (though comfortably distinct). Though these tracks are largely mellow, it grooves with enough soul to keep the listener from falling asleep. <br /> <br />The music has an indigenous quality to it; I'm using that term a little loosely. It just makes me think of the music that the aboriginal musicians would be making today if most of them hadn't been killed off.  <br /> <br />Cripple Crow will make a superb addition to your collection. The album offers a nice balance of longer songs interspersed with shorter ones, which comprise about 80 minutes worth of fun, contemplative and poetic tunes to keep your heart at peace. <br /> <br />I rate this album at 4.2 stars. It improves after several listens, like Nick Drake albums did for me.

B00005JL7Q|4.0|Wil (Hugh Grant) is the ultimate dilettante.  His father wrote a famous Christmas song and he has been living off the royalties all his life.  He thinks of everything in terms of 30 minute intervals.  Everyone in his life tells him he is wasting his life and it has no substance. <br /> <br />He is looking for relationships that fit into his lifestyle - no strings short term.  So he decides to date single moms.  The problem is how to meet them.  His first idea is to attend a single parents mixer.  This creates its own problem because he doesn't have a kid.  So he creates a 2 year old but he doesn't have any idea how a two year old acts or what a two year old can do.  This blows up in his face. <br /> <br />One day a boy shows up on his doorstep, Marcus (newcomer Nicholas Hoult) - (it's a little more complicated than that).  And he hires him to pretend to be his son.  He meets a beautiful single mom, Rachael (Rachael Wiess).  But things get complicated when Marcus has ideas of his own.  He wants Wil as his dad and tries to set him up with his offbeat mom (Toni Collette).   <br /> <br />The real story is not Wil trying to find a temporary mate but that of Wil and Marcus.  Wil is the real child, a man who has never had to grow up, and Marcus the child adult, a boy forced to grow up too fast.  These are the wonderfully touching and truly inspirational scenes. <br /> <br />Of course, the Wil and Rachael story has to blow up and does.  The movie has a touching and almost over the top ending but it works. <br /> <br />This is the typical Hugh Grant character but he has found a way to make it interesting and new.  Toni Collette continues to amaze me.  She can do anything.  And Nicholas Hoult is perfect, let's see if he can keep it up. <br /> <br /> <br />DVD EXTRAS: <br />Spotlight on Location: Making of About a Boy - A typical promo featurette running 11 minutes with book author Nick Hornby, directors Chris & Peter Weitz, actors Hugh Grant, Nicholas Hoult, Rachael Weiss andToni Collette.  Although it's a promo it is very good.  <br /> <br />Feature Commentary by Chris & Peter Weitz <br /> <br />Deleted Scenes - You have a choice of the deleted scenes only or with director's commentary. 10 deleted scenes totaling 14 minutes.  I prefer the director's comments as you are told why the scene was deleted.   <br /> <br />Music Videos - Silent Sigh and Something to Talk About by Badly Drawn Boy plus About a Boy Soundtrack spot <br /> <br />Badly Drawn Boy - 21 minute interview with the singer Badly Drawn Boy <br /> <br />Santa Super Sleigh - The full song in video form <br /> <br />English to English dictionary - This really should be British to American dictionary.  It shows a scene with a typical British term then an American definition.  Most words are well known but it is still fun to watch (3 minutes) <br />
0767827694|4.0|The mind wants what the mind wants and when you're watching a movie it is usually to know what is going on. Orlando defies all logic spanning a couple centuries without really explaining why or how but it is beautiful to watch; the costumes, the scenery and of course Tilda Swinton. At points it does seem a bit long with no end in site but if you can lift yourself above storyline, lack of plot and the usual things that carry a movie you may find enjoyment in getting to know the struggle of one man who becomes a woman and the times they live in as they learn about love, deception, jealousy, devotion, admiration, honor and the rights of the sexes. This movie is not completely true to the book as the director added on a world war in an attempt to update the movie had Woolf written the story later. I have seen this movie a few times and still enjoy it. It is worth watching at least twice to wrap your mind around it. Orlando made me fall in love with Tilda. If you're a fan of Billy Zane you get to see him ride in on a horse, sweep Orlando off her feet and depart as quickly as he came. The movie isn't about him or their relationship, as the title stipulates, it's about Orlando.
